content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												This is not a perfect game, and I doubt it ever will be. It is however one of a kind, there are very few games that feature sandbox mode business building in the 18th century. There is the element of starting up with your preferred business, finding a wife and starting a family - this is pretty much the gameplay of your first generation. As you build up more cash you can buy titles in order to buy more businesses, upgrade your house and also qualify for political offices. Some businesses are better suited to later generations - such as Carpenter, this business will be much more profitable if you also own a woodcutter hut which then can supply the wood needed and sell surplus to the markets (without this the need to buy wood from the expensive markets makes it quite not very profitable).All level 1 businesses can be levelled up to levelled up (1 - 2 - 3) which offers further production options and perks that can aid production, add workers and even fend off burglars. You can even decide to go a little crazy and start killing people, you will be taken to court and be sent to prison, fined or even executed for this. There is so much you can do with this game.I've seen some reviews saying that it has a clunky interface (it probably does if you aren't used to the game) but most of these people seem unwilling to learn how to play the game, if you want a simple game then stick to candy crush. I will repeat it is not perfect, you will probably find many bugs but there isn't anything that makes it unplayable and it can be very entertaining if you let it!

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Absolutely underrated and unrivaled is how I would best summarize this series. This is particularly true with "Renaissance" as the latest and most comprehensive addition.Ambitious at the outset, what The Guild II Renassiance successfully accomplishes (with minor flaws) is a faithful recreation of medieval life and its jarring transition to early capitalism. Everything falls under the purview of this simulation -- politics, economics, family, and what I view as its most compelling aspect -- murder, intrigue, and the subsequent games one might play with a court system as an extension of the earlier mentioned politics.It's a sociopath's kind of simulator. "The Guild II" has always, from my perspective, marketed itself on the player's ability to place the daughters of your character's enemies into prostitution, engineer methods of spreading plague to your rivals, and of course, its ability to rouse the jolly spirit of arson in everyone.Here is something that happened in one of my playthroughs. An AI owner of the town's hospital would not leave the building so that I could murder them and buy the deed to the place. My character had a high charisma and was able to fabricate a claim that the owner of the hospital had committed a serious crime and went to the court with said claim. From the AI's reluctance to leave the hospital, they failed to appear for the court summons and were deemed a persona non grata. The AI still did not leave the hospital at this point, so I firebombed the facility. As the building was engulfed in flames, the AI owner immediately stormed out of the place and was quickly lynched in the streets by the townsfolk. I got my hospital and without murder.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												One of the best games I've ever played. Mostly in multiplayer. I remember the old times with timeout issues. They are mostly gone, but there are till some bugs. I'm glad developers are still working on it. It even has a fairly big modding community. I've been playing it for a long time, got it in a computer magazine, and I've decided to support the developers once more, so I've bought it on steam. I realise that there were lot of different companies running The Guild since Europa 1400.This game has a great potential. It's one of the most complex games, but yet it is easy to play, but difficult to master. It's an economic simulator.At the beginning you create your character, there are not many options in design, but this is not The Sims. The more important things are the stats and class. You can even chose between 2 religions, protestant and catholic, the only difference in my opinion is that you can only build church of your religion. You can change it in a church.So to the classes: there are four of them: Patron, Craftsman, Rogue and Scholar.They are not balanced. The devs and modders are trying to fix it, but it's still not it. I hope guild 3 will be better balanced.My first try was Rogue (obviously). It was the easiest way to accumulate a lot of money, get rid of concurrence and hold the highest position in the council. In fact, in about 30 years, I've had a huge mansion on a hill and I stopped playing.That's the biggest problem of the game. In singleplayer, it gets repetitive.Scholar is second easier, maybe even easiest, because you don't break the law for your job. But you should. Where is the fun? :DYou just build a church and people pay you just to go in there. You can easily make friends and make everybody hate your enemies. I personally like the cemetery, because of all the satanists praying there. Even more than in church.Craftsman is my favorite, because it has a lot of challenge, mostly in big cities flooded with concurence. The job of a craftsman is to make something from something else. That's different from patron and scholar who just collects their materials, and rogue who steals it. I don't play for patron much, because I find it boring. So no review of that profession. Every profession is necesarry in a town, maybe except of the rogue. Without patron, craftsman cannot produce clothes and so on, and scholar cannot make medicine or other stuff. It is probably the most frequent reason of dying or bankrupting. No scholar means no hospital, what almost certainly means death. I hate that AI does'n really have a stock of more expensive medicine. Overall AI isn't so Intelligent, but in recent updates and modpacks it is more agressive and more complex. I hope that it will be better in The Guild 3.So I think that's enough for now, nobody is reading it anyway, I will maybe write another one regarding some other features, like marriage, children, burning down your neighbours house or kidnapping your mother in law. I'm really looking forward to The Guild 3, in fact, I would gladly do alpha/beta testing.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												This is possibly my favourite game in the entire RTSRPG genre, and I am confident in what I am saying.This game requires you to play for at least a few hours to learn the basics, as it takes time to progress and make profit of your business. (Unless you're a rogue)++ Edit: Patch 4.20 was released 22nd December! Definitly improved the gameplay, and I recommend it even more than before!Bottom-LineI would only and very much recommend this game to anyone who looks for an RTS that isn't trendy, there's quite few people I know which enjoyed this game. If your more into killing, return to C&C or SC. It lightly delivers an RPG feel, has a great economic system, and unique way of going about the game from a military point of view. Not only does it provide objective based rules, there is a sandbox to try out new things for single and multiplayer. However, you have to weigh bugs, your patience, and an absent multiplayer(online)  into playability of the game. The multiplayer does not work very well if you're playing with even 1 AI Dynasty, as it De-Syncs the other player most likely after 1 round (24 minutes normal speed). It's possible to counter with constant saving/loading, but for me It's not worth it. This is the first game I've tried of the series, so I can't compare/contrast of the others, but I have to say its a good play. I've played 250 hours alltogether with my second account. I paid sale price for this game and I definitely got my money's worth. Any game nearing 100 hours of enjoyable/challenging experience is no doubt in my opinion is something to definitely try out!

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												I had a bit of fun with the game. I enjoyed building up my dynasty. I enjoyed attempting to climb the political ladder while preparing for a revolution. I enjoyed the satisfaction of advancing my station in society. But the game just seems unfinished with broken or strange mechanics, nonsense dialogue, and game breaking glitches.Building a dynasty is cool. You get married, you have kids. Simple. But having a flourishing dynasty is useless because you're only allowed to control three characters at a time, and if you stop controlling one at any time, they're gone for good. If you have a member halway up the political ladder and you need to control another member of your family so they can start having kids of their own, you're out of luck. You have to make a choice. Do most of my kids end up unmarried and childless, or do I abandon my political career for them?Some of the broken mechanics involved the game permanently being stuck on pause and reloading a previous save does nothing. Others are the strange way you manage your dynasty, down to the weirdest dialogue. I understand it's a sim, but when my wife and mistress are both referred to as "him", or when people spout off random dialogue during a discussion, it breaks the immersion a bit. Another broken mechanic is the EXTREMELY limited space in which you can build. The maps are small and the slightest hill will prevent you from placing a building. This leaves you with massive wide open spaces in an already tight fit. The only way I found to slightly get around this was to place different buildings in the same spot before they could be built in order to form a grotesque super structure.But good luck playing the game if you decide to buy it anyway. There's no manual.Ultimately, I never got to complete the game. The game ended up breaking after I had basically taken over the whole town. Would I play it if it was more polished and didn't feature a stifling dynasty tree? Yeah. It's not a bad concept. They just didn't do a good job of it.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game, but it is too bugged to enjoy. And I'm not even talking about the animation glitching and texture clipping, or people just standing around because they are unable to get to their destination kind of bugs, I can live with that, I'm talking about the game destroying bugs and there are a lot... Also tried it with the Fajeth's MegaModPack 0.8 and Legacy ModPack 2.02 (separately of course), and even though they do fix a lot of things, sooner or later you will have to restart the game because it will became unplayable. After awhile you get sick and tired of so many restarts, and after constant fear that something may bug the hell out, you have to admit to yourself that the game became repulsive.It's a shame that there are not more games like this, but seeing how many problems this one have, I guess it is understandable.

number of helpful: 11 of 19 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												(Taken from my Guild 2 Review)This game claims to be an RPG... it isn't. What it is is a management sim and it ain't a very deep one at that. For something that's supposed to be about you living the medieval life there's not an awful lot of you livin' a life and probably a bit too much of you micro-managing your businesses and your employees. It is possible to set the AI to manage the buisnesses you build but you're very unlikely to make a sustanible profit doing that. The political system seems interesting at first but once you've climbed to the top it doesn't feel very fulfilling, and it doesn't add anything to the game to make you want to continue playing longer. The family system could've been interesting if it wasn't for the fact that it requires almost no effort what-so-ever. The most complicated thing you'll do is court your mate, but all that consists of is using four or five actions in the right order to increase your prospective spouse's affection, but each of these actions have a linked cool down with the rest so you have to wait a good few hours of ingame time (you can speed up the clock thankfully) before you can perform the next compliment. Children you send to school with a push of a button and there's no need to keep either parent at home to look after them either.Combat does exist in this game as does criminal actions but it's all rather pointless, you'll be far more successful running a lawful business than you ever would a criminal one and using actions like threats or murder are far too risky and made pointless by the fact that you can just bribe anyone and everyone into liking you.I find it hard to decide whether or not to recommend this game. Yes i've been critical but as a management game it's not bad and i've certainly played worse. It does carry an interesting premise, if not a particularly well implimented one. What it comes down to with me is, tho, the fact that it claims to be an RPG and a medieval life simulator and it's just not.A word of advice if you still wish to pick this game up go for the Renaissance stand-alone expansion since it has everything that both the main game and the Pirates expansion offers.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												TL;DR version: this game is fantasic whether you are into being a criminal mastermind, Political powerhouse or a simple tradesman.Well to say this game is great is an understatement. I've played for several hours and i still think i have just barely gotten into it. Personally i like to play the rogue and its a rare game that instead of just having you have to be careful of the guards...this game allows you to apply for an office of political power and then use the guards to arrest your opponents. Guy not paying the protection money? send a thug around to spy on him, get some dirt on a crime he did and either take him to court or just arrest him outright, guy trying to collect hush money from your thieves and working girls? have them whip him up a refreshing poisoned drink!Now for the less criminally minded there are still so many (in fact probably more) Legal ways to earn money and rise to power. mining gems and aking them into some jewlery, making baked goods from a network of farms and mills and even running a bank. the game offers so much and concidering that i picked it up for around £4.49 for the complete package. I feel like i ripped steam off!

content:
Posted: January 22
												If I somehow ended up on a desert island and could bring only one game with me, this with Fajeth's MegaMod installed would be it. It's rare that a game this ambitious comes anywhere close to achieving its potential, and when it does it's usually riddled with bugs. Well, the vanilla version of this game is pretty bug-riddled, but thankfully this game has such a loyal following that some modders took it upon themselves to keep fixing issues long after it was no longer profitable for the developing company to keep doing so, and the result is the most deeply immersive and complex life simulator that's ever been created. It's a little bit sims, and a little bit anno, and it's all good.

												The different things you can do to earn money are extremly unbalanced, only a few let you actually survive. content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												The ideas behind this game what pulls you in. Unique game.Pros:-To be able to choose real life like professions.-Craft many items and create automated trade routes to supply your shop while you attend to your bussiness.-Check market details of each city and plan your next haul.-Become a rich, known family and try your luck in politics.-Starting as a commoner and becoming a noble family amongs other known people and more titles.-You may conquer an entire city using economy alone.-You can see the interiors of each building while you and your employees working. Kind of satisfying to watch as you "Pay bonus" to you employees or using "Goad workers" heheCons:-Graphics are outdated yet interior deisngs still looks good.-Game AI is not stable.-Game engine is troubling at times. You have the feeling of weird bugs stalking you.-Some professions designed good while others, like rogue, not working well. Bugs and mechanic problems.-If AI bugs sometimes economic balance between items goes crayz. Once, I happen to be the only person who is supplying the market with food and clothing even though there are 4 rich familys in this crowded city who owned shops. AI simply stops working sometimes.

												I am mixed about this game. Bought it to get a feel for when Guild 3 came out....I bought a farm for grain, then a windmill to turn grain into flour, then a Weaver for cloth from the wool from the farm, then a bakery to turn flour to biscuits, then a mine for iron, then a foundary to turn iron into tools and then spent my time getting stuff to where was needing and selling the surplus. Would I just be doing this same process slowly taking over each and every building?I started a scholar to try...  will this be same thing? Rogue? I Feel a LOT less flare for it now. Was great at first though.. now.. not so sure.I though the RPG element would add something that city builders lacked (I played Skylines and it was just this process non stop), but its not enough to keep me hooked, even though I love the initial idea behind it.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												I won't write much, because if I start, I wont stop. So for TL;DR sake :Dont buy unless you will play with friends (Need Tunngle for that), or just only tend to play games for a few hours at a time. (More under Cons).Pros :- Its fun, and unique- Lots of replayability ~100 hr- Mischievous business tactics. How fun would it be to own a hospital, and in order to assume market control, you just burned down all the other hospitals? Plus, you get more customers in more ways than one ; )^ Or just assasinate all the workers- So many ways to play it, from owning a simple bakery to a massive supply chain, or becomming the ruler of a village. If you have enough money, you can even my an estate and start wars between countries!- Multiplayer is awesome, expecially if you like messing with your friends. (Oops, you're wife was assasinated? Wonder who did that..)Cons :- Bugs. Like opening a Sarcophagus after a thousand years of fermenting human. You NEED the community created patches, however, said patches also add new features. Just make sure either way to get them!- AI absoulutely kicks the bucket if you play long enough. After maybe 3-4 hours, their entire family dies of old age and you just win. Even if you don't touch them. You really need people to play with for this reason.- Online portion is dead, and their servers are gone. To play with friends, you need the glorious Hamachi or Tunngle <-.Just pray to GOD Guild III is actually made. And thank the community this game is still alive, since the developers dont do sh*t.

Product received for free
												standalone expansion and adds many things from buildings to maps and 8 new classes. Lightly delivers an RPG feel, has a great economic system, and unique way of going about the game from a military point of view. Not only does it provide objective based rules, there is a sandbox to try out new things for single and multiplayer. However, you have to weigh bugs, your patience, and an absent multiplayer(online) into playability of the game. However, the community has a way around the multiplayer through the use of third party programs that allow players to join games through their Lan. This is the first game I've tried of the series, so I can't compare/contrast of the others, but I have to say its a good play.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												This Game is a perfect Example for a good Idea badly realised. You start with a single workshop and are bound to build an Empire. But You should be very carefull, which Craft You choose, because there are many worksops very dependend on the Market for raw materials - and this Market only has wares someone produces, that means You or Your KI-Opponent. But the KI is so bad, that some wares are never produced at all and so your workshop soon goes out of materials and becomes bankrupt. The KI for Automanagement is even worse (on Autoselling and -producing, the KI even sells the raw materials needed for crafting, so Your workers will be without work and You again will be bankrupt), so You have to do the mikromanagment on Your own - all the time. This may be nice at the beginning, when You have only one shop, but already in the midgame You will have about 5 to 7 shops, and neither of them will work, if You dont sell and buy and produce every Item by Yourself.But even if You are ready to play a Game like that, even You like the mikromanagment, I Wouldnt recommend the Game. Because You need to do the Mikromanagment of Your family, too. Find a mate, educate your children and so on - and of course become elected in court, visit the doctor, eat, drink, sleep, all of it at the same time. And a lot of the features arent even explained or seem to have an effect. So none of my characters has ever eaten, because there are no negative effects, at least none I could see.With all of this to do, im lacking the Game "Guid". A  Game where you had to raise money to fight Your opponent via intrigue, violence and trickery. The foundation for a good Game is there - the economic processes are quite nice and it is fun to bring your first shop to maximum level. But by then the KI of Your opponents and the catastrophic and suicidal automanaging-processes destroy every fun.If You wanna play "The Guild" wait for the Guild III or play "The Guild I" Not this. spare Your 10 bucks.plz notice that english is not my first language

content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												Very ambitious game, poorly executed.The start of the game is very fun, there's lots of exciting things to do and the game appears to have great potential and the game appears to be extremely deep... first impressions of this game are very good. However, after the early-game, the economy becomes unworkable, your businesses grow so complex that they become unmanagable, and the AI factions will be rising up the courts because of regular mouse glitches making you bribe the wrong people.The economy system is completely broken. The map will always run out of raw resources unless you (the AI will never do this) set up a business to harvest them yourself, but this costs huge amounts of money to set up - money which you do not have in the early game. As you supply raw ingredients to the market, other factions make use of this raw resource and generate huge profits from very little investment on their part. And even though you have a monopoly on a raw resource, you have no control over the price at which you sell that resource.The mouse controls regularly glitch, which can be extremely frustrating when you're in court and you have to click and bribe the correct NPCs in a very short time limit. Also, as your businesses begin to grow, you will need to start automating the management of your buildings - this automation is very primitive and is very glitchy and frustrating to set up. Also.. there's no pause... the game just runs very, very slowly...?The more time you invest into this game, the more you realise how broken it is. This game isn't worth your time.

												It's RPG + Simulation + City Building + Economy + Politic.The game lack of tutorial, watch basic guide first before you jump in.have a few bug here and there but still playable.Common issue: 1. when you alt + tab then get into the game again the sapebar is not working. Solution:Press alt again, the spacebar will work .2. When you're on pause, then you click on the cart then click on the unload button and it's destination. It'll open the destination building menu and will not give you option to unload the item. Solution: If you notice, when you're on pause all things getting slow. When you click on unload button, wait for below title bar show choose destination before you click on the building. Or you can just change the speed for a while.If it keep opening the building menu, press escape then back to the game again

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
The Guild II Renaissance is currently on sale for around 2 USD. For that price you can probably afford the risk if you think this kind of game matches your game preferences. Be aware though that this game is single-player only. The original, The Guild Gold Edition, is currently on sale for the same price, and that one is multi-player. I don't own the Steam edition of the original, but I do remember it being really good multi-player entertainment.Edit: A kind reader left a notice that actually The Guild II Renaissance do have LAN support for multi-player games. You can for instance use Hamachi or similar software to play it with friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												A flawed yet great game that blends the control of The Sims with an economy, politics, sabotage, assasination and fighting in general without wetting your pants every five seconds (For clarification your people don't eat, poop, and sleep. You control when they work, what they work on, who they marry ect), all set in the rennaisance era of Sweden, Denmark and Germany (Or the Hanse).Start a bandit camp and put tolls on the roads.Run a hospital and sell your medicine.Open a blacksmith's shop and make "Only the finest weapons and armor".Run for mayor and control what happens in your town.Weave cloth, make bricks, mix dyes, run an inn or pub, farm, mine or log.Smuggle, extort, bribe, murder and sabotage to remove your opposition and make yourself rich.Though it does have its flaws, the starting splash movie is glitchy and freezes the game before it can start, requireing you to alt tab to make it un-freeze, multiplayer is a tad broken with you having to download a third party client (Tunngle for instance) to be able to use it, and even then desync is very common. Plus multiple other small bugs.In all though, I give it a 7/10 and I recommend it to anyone.

Be aware though that this game is single-player only. The original, The Guild Gold Edition, is currently on sale for the same price, and that one is multi-player. I don't own the Steam edition of the original, but I do remember it being really good multi-player entertainment.Edit: A kind reader left a notice that actually The Guild II Renaissance do have LAN support for multi-player games. You can for instance use Hamachi or similar software to play it with friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2012
												This is perhaps my favorite game of all.. due mainly to my love of the time period and the gameplay as a whole. You basically are the patriarch of a family and spend your life making a dynasty to stand the test of time. With 4 classes to choose from the game has a near infinite amount of replay value and there is no particular goal in dynasty mode but to survive and outlast the other dynasties. From peasants to near Royalty you will influence your city and nation to greatness through noble businesses or underground criminal syndicates. Whether you choose to own farms and INNs or preach at churches or make potions at apothecaries you will find your place in this historical world.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2011
												What an interesting game this is. It sort of spans across multiple genres - it's part RPG, it's part city-builder and it's part trade simulation. It's really a fantastic blend which offers an enormous potential for a perfect game, but sadly the game falls just short of that mark due to a cumbersome interface and some annoying bugs. But the new developer who took over the title (Runeforge) has made appreciable improvements and bug fixes which let's you really enjoy the game.If you're willing to put up with a bit of a tough learning curve and a rough interface then this title is something that can be extremely fun and exciting.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												Great concept, rotten implementation. :(Both The Guild and the Guild II seem to work up to a point and then they fall flat on their faces.1) When you pause the game, it does not actually pause. Theoretically you need to browse the enemy stats and you don't need the enemy to be continuing to grow while you try to absorb that information.2) The game straight jackets you into a forced pace / style of play which is extremely frustrating if you want to play it to your own style or with any sort of freedom of choice.3) The one mechanism which might compensate for the above two issues is the business route planner, which is limited, very cumbersome to set up and basically broken. The game applies an arbitray minimum sale value and will not deliver goods below that. This leaves you paying wages but earning nothing while you do so.Effectively the game balance just does not work.IF YOU BUY THIS GAME YOU WILL JUST GET ANNOYED AT HOW BEAUTIFUL IT COULD BE AND HOW BROKEN IT IS.B a s i c a l l y   i t   i s   s t i l l   i n   b e t a !

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												So I decided to try out this game after it was on sale. Had a difficult time at start because there was no tutorial. Found some help online and turned out it was pretty easy after all. Anyway, I decided to start on a map with three different cities. All went fine, I made some money and eventually my family became pretty big. One of the kids got kidnapped and tortured as soon he was grown up. So I decided it might be better to let him move to one of the other towns, since no one knew him there and it could be a chance to make more profit. I made him walk from Bergen (Norway) to Londen (G.B.). He finally arrived there and I decided the poor soul needed a woman in his life. Before he found himself a wife, he got murdered. The rest of the family seems to be fine, even though they'll never know what happened to their son.Besides not having a tutorial, I enjoyed the game. EDIT: Turns out there was a patch for this game (underneath properties -> beta -> select the patch and let it download). You'll find a tutorial ported from the originial game in it.

A host of horrid hermaphrodites that plagued the roads and marketplaces with thieving and undue taxes. Eventually, however, hostilites against my group came to a head. A rival family in the Town decided to set up shop too close to my own front of a legitimate business. Of course, I could not allow this. As such, I proceeded to murder the wife of the man of the family in broad daylight, in turn creating several witnesses to my sins. As a result of the crime, I was then pursued by the authorities in the name of justice. This resulted in my death. Until...MY ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ GOONS CAME TO THE RESCUE! AW YUSS SON BREAKING ME OUT. content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												This is by far a unique game when it comes to economic/political/simulation games. This manages to be a very entertaining game with lots of depth and strategy involved while also being light hearted and not too serious.It can be a bit daunting at times but reading up on the internet can help start you off, The campaign in Pirates of the European Seas also helps you get accustomed to how the game is played.An important thing to note is that there is no Dev support for the game anymore BUT it does have a very active and successful modding community, it's also highly recommended that you look for the latest legacy mod to fix the bugs and add some extra features.If you've got a close group of friends this game can be a blast with planning secret back room deals, political intrigues, sabotage and an in depth criminal system. On the top layers it is also pretty fun to run a proper business and try to improve the local towns prosperity.  Basically it's about as awesome as GoT but on a much smaller scale xD Sadly no massive armies or foreign lands to explore.If you Roleplay, this would probably be the best game to use as a setting, The depth of actions and choices you can make is staggering.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I had the box version years ago in Germany but moved to the states and lost it. Once I saw that this game was bought out and a new patch was released + Guild 3 announced I just had to buy it again. This is truly one of my all time favorites.You can build an empire and crush your enemies (or friends if you feel like it).  You are not stuck with the same job but can switch once you progress within the game.The game experience is quiet unique and multiplayer is what makes this game really fun. The only downside is the out-if-sync issues. Once you have a few years in-game time the chances of getting a random disconnects from the game get greater. The newest patch has helped a lot but I feel that it will never be perfect. Maybe the Guild 3 will fix everything...

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												This game is a lot like Oblivion, it's a buggy piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥but in the right frame of mind you can lost in itand lose entire nights of your life to it. You'll frequently find pathfinding not working as intended or town meetings being skipped yet results of that meeting still being attained.The tactics in this game are absolutely beautiful, from managing family relations, finding a mate to expand your linieage and sabotaging your competitor's shops.Having trouble with some guy? Why not fabricate some evidence against him and then convict him extra harshly because you just happen to be the town's judge?The possibilities for ♥♥♥♥ing other people up are endless, diverse, rich, satisfying and generally amazing. Too bad you'll need a relatively high bug tolerance to have those moments.Whilst the bugs make the game by no means unplayable, it certainly can make it a bit of a struggle every now and again.8/10, would recommend unless you have a short temper.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												This game touched on a lot of great ideas. It combines an economic simulation with building up a dynasty by giving you control over the individuals and their abilities.  The problem is it feels like an alpha. Even if the latest beta patch did improve the game in terms of glitches and crashes, the barebone mechanics will drive you insane. For example, at the forefront of this game sits trading. The tools given to you for this purpose will just infuriate you. Sure, you can micromanage the trade routes in your chain of production, but this aspect is barely implemented. It's pointless to explain, but bottom line you'll find yourself tweaking the routes over and over again. The game doesn't handle properly overproduction mixed with multiple goods to transfer, partial mid route dropoffs are broken, starting the route only allows you to select the quantity of goods present in your buildings at that moment in time, and the list can go on. You'll end up transporting only one type of goods between point A and B. You can turn on the AI for this, but if you do, expect to get even more frustrated. The AI is making dumb decisions such as dropping off finished goods back to the building that produced the original raw resource (probably because it was in the way, who knows), buying goods from the market even though you have buildings that produce the goods in your production chain, filling up your buildings with raw materials leaving no room for the finished goods. Oh don't worry, this is not the only aspect lacking in the game, but it's by far the most important.This game is the perfect example of stretching the goals and having to deal with a scope creep that got out of control, leading to something that simply can't be called a finished product.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												The Guild is a wonderful concept, but this game suffers from a sleugh of bugs/stability issues/ and a horrible AI. The latest patch is not part of the steam download and must be downloaded from their website, and the "best" patch is the beta one, due to the developers not wanting to release a new one until they're sure it's finalized. Nothing in the game is streamlined. AI for your buildings made this worse for me which forces you to take the time to micromanage each business individually. Characters are seperated into professions which makes sense, however the seperation between building functions within the professions becomes extremely tedious, getting to the point were it sometimes doesn't even make sense. The rogue profession especially is limited by this. As far as money and the economy goes, it is fairly easy for the economy to crash. The longer you play through a game you will notice the economy starting to slowly worsen. Despite rival dyanasties reaching massive ammounts of money midway through the game their businesses weren't producing anything, and only base level items and resources were being put into the market. Despite this, it would usually become more profitable in the long run to also only have your businesses produce the 1st tier of items as well. Nobody would be buying the high tier ones, and as the supply went up the profit from selling them would go down for me until it would stay consistantly low for a few turns. This was an issue that stayed constant from almost every game I started, regardless of my profession. As I was playing a Rogue I would in turn be limited to this as well. It would take longer to upgrade my buildings, pay for employees, etc. since what was being stolen was only the low tier items the AI was producing. The flipside to this was that if I essentially wanted to exploit the game you could build a pub, play dice, and just keep reloading your save until you actually win a large sum of money and repeat when needed. To be fair, I was playing the game with the legacy mod installed with the right patch, and this fixed many glitches regarding the AI, but did  not fix some of the combat and job  issues with your characters taking prolonged periods of time before they would actually do what they were told to do.  To elaborate, the game isn't horrible. It's just that if you're expecting to the game to run smoothly you're going to be dissapointed, finding how long it takes to do even the simplest of tasks in RTSes taking much more time.. Likewise, if you're expecting the game to become as in depth as far as the economy for it goes, you will also be dissapointed. It's fun to mess around in if you just take it for what it is, but with issues going uncorrected and the use of an outdated game engine for this stand alone "expansion," I can't get behind it. It's a wonderful idea and I really like the game's direction, so I feel very backhanded for saying I can't recommend this game to my friends. In the end however; I can't see myself paying even $10 for it if I had known about the issues I'd have with it before.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Great game idea, terrible execution. Has a lot of crash issues (somehow even manages to crash windows to the point where hard reboot is needed for some folk), saves have a 50/50 chance of being corrupted, the pathing is wtf worthy if not downright frustrating; the controls become really annoying after a while (don't even get me started on combat). It has its cool moments, but honestly it plays like a steam early access game and it's from 2006 (granted Renaissance did come out in 2010, but it seems to me that the engine was practically unchanged in the two games). I might have a soft spot for this game because it's both a political and and economical simulator in one game, but honestly I would advise people to stay away from this particular game unless you're really into strategy/tycoon and the like. You're only going to go out being frustrated (and maybe a bit confused, as the game doesn't really have a good tutorial). Maybe wait for The Guild III as it's in development right now.

												The Sims medieval done very right. Control your dynasty, become a mayor or a torturer, grow your family,  amass wealth, and much more!Become the scholar, and gain influence with faith or shady rouge who kidnaps the scholar to demand ransom. It's all based on your choice how you will progress. Definitly a game worth your money and your time! You prefer more calm experience? content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												Love the game.  I was able to live vicariously through my characters bringing my family from organized crime and into politics and banking to become the most powerful man in Danzig.  My first wife contracted leporasy, was an unforutnately a patron and had only gotten pregnant with one child.  So I divorced her and had her killed at my mercenary fortress outside the city where my men were killing bandits and collecting tolls.  I also used my mercenarys and thugs to track and inform on other criminals while my men at the thieves guild pickpocketed while the gypsies and wanderers I hired to tell fortunes and use crystal balls to shill people out of money.  I abused every political position I was in to get ahead, once while I was summoned to court as I was head on the dungeon I order my bailors to bring in the procecutor to be lashed giving the appearence he missed court.  All evidence against me was dismissed.  I rose in political office until I was Marshal and head of the guards whom I made sure were not around whilst my men broke the bones or killed my enemies.  I also brought my new wife up in the political chain until I had become sovereign and her the head Magistrate in Danzig.  We rule the city with an Iron fist.  We wiped out the rival crime family  through ambushes between cities, setting houses on fire and slaughtering inhabitants as they run out of flaming buildings and condemming buildings my thugs damage abusing my power as Sovereign while I banished anyone in the political office who would not vote my wife or children's way in application of office.  A rival family of doctors and churchmen still stand in my way and surprisingly tend to be more resilient.  We find their honesty unsettling.  I have allowed one of their family members into a low level political office.  To keep my enemies close.  I have since turned my eyes to the larger city of Hamburg where I now plan to send my son as he graduates from university to begin banking and with our blood money we use to purchase noble titles with an end goal.  For the head of my house to become King.  No one will stand in our way.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												I liked this game at first, lots of potential here.  But the more I played it the more buggy it became, and so it became less enjoyable.  Problems ranged from corrupted files (crashes to the desktop when you load it meaning hours of gameplay lost unless you have auto-save enabled), lag on a map I didn't have previously playing the map on another file, inability to have my character enter a building he owns so he can work there, not being able to return my fishing boat to the fishing shack, mouse suddenly not able to click on buildings or characters, etc.  Idk if there is a patch for some of these problems, and if there is please someone tell me how to go about getting that, but otherwise this growing list of glitches has made an otherwise fun game unplayable.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												I am surprised that this game is getting a "very positive" rating; and the game is more than just quirky or glitchy; the game is so unrefined and plagued be so many bugs, that it's almost unplayable. Just moving the cart around can be difficult because of the poor implemented interface. I'm a very forgiving gamer, and I have to say that I wish I could get my money back for this title.I will admit that the concept is a good one, and if the interface wasn't so glitchy, this would be a fun game, but due to the bugs, this game is just too frustrating to look past it's faults.Asside from those issues, the graphics are lousy, the game chugs along and is very slow. I have quite the robust PC with plenty of RAM and this game just kills the resources.Honesly, your money could be better spent elsewhere, and the producers of this game should be ashamed by the poor quality here.

												Hello fellow internets! I bought The Guild II Renaissance along with the other 2 games for only 2 dollars via steam winter sale, i'm 10 hours or so in the game this is the story of my 3rd character first 2 where me learning the game, after the story i will tell you the Pro's/Cons of the game as of now... The Story Of My Dynasty	My dynasty was a rogue by the name of "Pimp King Pantaloons" we were a walking nightmare slaying any peasant who stands before us, kidnapping and pillaging other dynastys to the point of breaking them, one day we went on trial cause we robbed like 8 houses outside of town and i decided to kidnap the person who was putting me on trial, after he failed to show up to the trail i chose to bleed him of his money, which was only 2,000 Gold, considering i was making like 10-20k gold a day thats kinda shet. Then i started running for office, and by the age of 50 became Sovergn and banished their entire guild...Best game ever﻿Pro's- Sandbox- Large/Small Maps- 4 Different class's Rogue/Craftsman/Scholar/Patron- Large modding community- Graphical OptionsCons- Multiplayer is not working- Local Multiplayer isn't working either aka Hamchi/Tunngle- Graphics- Some Crashs (Nothing File Corrupting) = Fixed by the modding community

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												So I picked up the base game in the sales it played ok though was really full of bugs most up to the point of making it unplayable but for the sale price it was really worth it so if you can pick that up go for it but stay away from the DLC!This DLC (Unsure about pirate one as I brought thme together) is so ridled with bugs it just does not make it playable at all, the first game I did it kept pausing itself and then after awhile just would not unpause had a memory leak and borked out so I had to task manager out of it, The second playthrough was met by placing a building and then well the building never built or anything... it was placed down and then was gone but I was still not allowed to rebuild it... Play 3 my character was completely invisible and I had no idea where he was... that is where I quit it! Don't even buy this in the sale it was rushed and in my professional opinion as a Games Developer "UNFINISHED" if this was sent to my QA department I'd fling it so far back into its design phrase you'd all have to wait another 4 years for it hahaa..If you really want to play it as I said DO NOT buy the DLC (Rennaisance or Pirates) just diver on over to the base game.. but I warn you that is full of bugs that at times take away vital features of the game (such as your courted girl refusing to enter the church or on my last playthrough the hospital just taking my money and ignoring me) In total I give the base game a 4/10 it has something but needs a lot of work it was rushed and in my eyes just a money earner, this DLC I give a 0/10 it is unplayable and marked by me as (UNFINISHED), Enjoy your night!

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												Not too bad.  This is probably a $2.49 game for the following reasons:- I don't quite see the replayability being very highOnce you get the game premise there's not much to changing professions.- The UI is deplorableThere's no way to intuitively just pick up the game - you HAVE to read the manual, and delays in dialogs appearing on the order of 3 seconds add to frustration.- There are bugsFor example, a UI element will get "stuck" and rendering the game unplayable.  Close the game and restart it and things work again.+ The game concept is nice+ The context overlaps with other games like Patrician (1400s Europe)+ The game is funny.  I gave a woman a dagger as a gift and she slapped me!  So yes - I recommend the game!

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												When I was 20 years old, I loved The Guild 2 so much. I had all the expansion packs and patches.I played The Guild 2 every night before bed, greatful to Nordic Games for announcing the 42.0 patch. "It will be so stable" I say. "420 Blaze it"My Dad hears me and tells me to study for College.I knew he was just jealous because I actually knew how to play.I called him a commoner.He unplugs my pc and sends me to bed. I am laughing now, I use a laptop.I lay in bed playing The Guild 2The warmth of my laptop on my legs.I see something beat me upIts the yellowsI am so angryThey send me a message"This is my bakery"They knock me out with their powerful OP units and steal my stuff.Im readyI tell the court what they did to meThey hate me tooIt hurts so much but I do it for my virtual gfI can feel my heart tearing as she breaks up with me anywayI give her a "Miracle remedy"I want to please herShe yells a mighty yell as she slaps me in the face with her love.My Dad walks inI look at him straight in the eye and say "I am only Googling the Kardashians"Dad is not disappointI throw the laptop out of my windowThe Guild 2 is love. The Guild 2 is life.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												This game is quite entertaining. There is plenty of things to do, and a lot of gameplay value. Learning about the game is quite interesting, and the game is deep enough to give you dozens or even hundreds of hours.It can be quite funny too. The character interactions are so bizarre and weird that the few first times I saw them I couldnt stop laughing.There is plenty to do. Crafting, business and family management, relationship, crimes, politics, character development, skills, story, multiple maps.Maybe there are bugs, maybe things arent perfect, but the game is quite enjoyable and unique. Check out other reviews to see if this is the best version, but overall, this is quite a good game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I have been a big gan of The Guild since i first touched the guild 1 years and years ago. I have all of them on cd still but decided to buy the steam version when it was on sale just to have a back up.Its somewhat of a niche game though. I highly doubt the vast majority of people would enjoy it. Its very slow and time consuming, especially if you go multiplayer. The game is incredibly buggy also. Most of the bugs are not game breaking but they can get very annoying. I reccomend heavily modding the game. Its fairly easy to do and mostly involves changing numerical values in text and if your able to understand basic html you shouldnt have a problem really working with the files to get what you need done. (i know the coding isnt in html but it isnt much more difficult than that to edit).Personally i love the game. Die Gilde i spent tons and tons of hours on. 2 I have quite a bit of time into as well just killing time at work and home. I personally like to make the game as difficult as possible for myself. I start with almost no money and a house and give the npcs a bunch of advantages. But for lighter game play id reccomend giving yourself a big advantage which is easily done by editing the config file and changing a few numbers.All in all id give it a 7.5/10 due mostly to bugs and difficulty setting up multiplayer matches (which require you to have all files exactly the same in a game that needs major editing to work at least somewhat properly). But i want to note this game is not going to be up everyones alley for certain and while i think people should at least try it i know many will be dissapointed.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I was really looking forward to playing this game however the mouse doesn't show up and this renders the game unplayable, I am running windows 10 Home with an i7 6700k/R9-390x.  From reading about other people who have had the same problem it looks like this game only works if you are running an older computer with an OS from around the time this game was first made. I am no computer expert though and I am sure someone more competent with computer's  could get it to work, however If that isn't you and you don't like searching through old obscure forum posts for hours and trying to manually change things inside of set up directories etc to try and get it to work I would suggest not buying this game. I tried many of the fix's that were suggested and none worked, I wasted 3-4 hours doing this and gave up. It would be amazing if the game developers would release a patch so it would work on newer windows 10 machines. At this point I am out money and can't play the game.  Game still looks like a lot of fun just wish I could play it :(

content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												After so many years in existance the new developers (Nordic Games, that bought the license after Jowood took a nosedive into the abyss) finally patched it up so it is as fantastic and magnificent as intended from the beginning. From having game-breaking multiplayer issues and a great amount of bugs (and no effective bugspray) to be a, for once, fully functional version of itself making it reach for the stars, past Sir God and Mr. Jesus to infinity and beyond to be remembered always for being the sole heir to the throne of sandbox-/trade-/building-/medieval-/dynasty-/family-/murder-/backstabbing-/priest-/political-/bishop-/smith-/♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥-/pirate-/robbery-/beer-/inn-/flu-/spouse-/babymaking-/dancing-/walking-/courtroom-/goad-/capitalistic-/bombing-/sabotage-/shipfaring-/buisness management-/woodcutter-/gravedigging-simulators with pretty deep RPG elements. Let's just say the game is pretty unique and as of now it's actually WORKING!metaphors aside this game is really good and now if you've ever wanted to try this game now is the best time to do it as the game is now fully playable. Also, as some reviewers pointed out before, The Guild 3 is on the way and Nordic Games are the right developers to get it done.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Update Jan.14.2017 Cold Hard Facts:  Game Launched July 2010 - Broken & Buggy beyond belief Latest Patch 4.211 released August 2015  (5 years worth of patches!!) - STILL tremendously Broken & Buggy. (Frankentstein himself functions better than this game) 6+ years after this game has released, Fanatical players see all negative reviews on steam as a personal attack on them & respond by trolling negative reviews with ad hominem arguments & smashing dislike buttons where applicable; effectively doing more to hurt the game they all love so much rather than help it. Original Review:TLDR: Broken beyond belief. Not worth your time even if it were free...Honestly, I tried really hard to have fun with this game. 11 to 12 hours of solid gameplay, 2 hours of learning form videos about this game on youtube, cause I was thinking: "there must be something I'm missing here. Either I just don't know about all the mechanics, or I'm doing something wrong, or both...". But no, none of that was the case. The problem with this game is that it is just plain broken. Out of all the mechanics in the game that are at the player's disposel, only 1 actually works (if only clumsilly).The impression I get from this game as far as what the dev's envisioned is bassically Crusader Kings turned Sims. Or even think of this game like this: turn House of Cards into a PC game, and set it in the medieval/renaissance era. Which, when hashed out on paper, sounds great and I think there's actually a need for a game like that in the PC market. Unfortunately, The execution on this game is just not there.The only mechanic that actually works 100% of the time in this game is the charchter's ability to make money, but making money in this game is not fun. it's a mindless 'Point & Click' chore. Every other mechanic is just down right broken.Want one of your character's to rob someone? Tough, cause it's broken. I actually took the time to find every single chacter on the map I was playing on (and I mean EVERYONE) and tried to rob them with both my main character and my "henchmen", and the game would not allow me to attempt to rob anyone. So then I thought: "ok, maybe it's the buildings that I'm supposed to rob". Tried to rob everysingle building on the map, and again, no dice. So why even have it in the game if it's broken?!?Want to bribe the Mayor to ellect you into office? Don't bother, because every other applicant will bribe him for the exact same amount you do, which essentially nullifies all the bribes given by everyone because he ends up equally favouring everyone. In one particualr ellection, I decided to show up to the council meeteing early so that I could bribe him right there in the council hall before the voting started. I then watched hillariously as every single npc in the council hall handed him a sack of money. I was like number 8 in line with my bribe. Needless to say, I wasted my money and so did the npc's.Want to Sabbotage a business owend by a competing faction? Tough nuts, because Sabbotaging a building doesn't have any effect on the business' abilty to function what so ever. Because you have to sabbotage it multiple times and there's a 7 hour cool down period on the sabbotage ability (in-game time of course), and by the time you've bombed the business enough for it to actually have an effect, someone's just going to lay charges against you and throw your bung-hole in jail. Sure, you can pull off 1 or 2 sabbotages with out having too much incriminating evidence floating around, but it takes more than that, so you will get caught. So therefore, pointless.I'm not even scratching the surface here. There are sooooooo many broken mechanics that I do not have the time or the patients to list them all here. Conclusion:I bought this game on sale for under 3 bucks, and I feel very lucky that I didn't spend any more then that. And please, don't buy into the youtube videos that supposedly show you how this game works and then claim its a "good game"....In fact, now that I think back, every video I watched never contained a single second of mid-game or even late-game play time. And that makes alot of sense, because this game is 'deceptivley' broken:In the first 2 hours of the first playthrough, you might feel proud that you've started a thriving business, gotten married and had kids to carry on your "Dynasty", and bought your familly a higher "Title", and that will give you the illusion that this game is "Fun". But then when you try to make use of all the game mechanics provided for you in order to progress further than that (i.e. get ellected in to office, hostel take-over of competing dynasty's buildings, bribery and blackmail, etc...), you'll slowly find that those game mechanics just do not work at all. And its sad. because the idea behind this game is so great. Motives for this game were great; method's in making this game were crack♥♥♥♥♥ There are early access games that are more pollished than this game, and bare in mind, this game is on it's 4th itteration already...So no, I can not, in good clean conciense, recommend this game, even if it were free, let allone 80% off. Sorry dev's, but you bought a really bad, sour apple here. Rumor has it there will be a "Guilds 3", and I really hope they're just that: Rumours....

My mother said to me- "Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.”

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												All right, so I'm giving this game a positive review, but it comes with caveats. I'm going to be frank, I love this game. If you and a few friends get together to play, or even on your own, it's ridiculously entertaining and will engage your interest for hours. BUT the caveat is that it has some bugs and breaks which are pains in the♥♥♥♥♥ Almost all of these bugs I've encountered revolve around the UI and it's either malfunctioning or non-existance in one case. Caravans travelling long distance can also get trapped and stuck on each other which is awfully annoying, but if they're your own then it can be rectified easily by assuming direct control. The political system is a bit broken in that once a family gets a monopoly on the higher offices, there's no way in except some thuggish skullduggery, and that dynasties will often completely ignore mutual assistance pacts and relationship when it comes to voting. Many times in the city council, the UI will tell me that I'm about to get a unanimous vote for some position, but often despite all their votes being "for me" they all wind up voting for my competitor instead, completely ignoring what was visibly a victory. I've dropped over 100,000 gold into the political process and absolutely could not get elected due to these issues with the election system, so if you're looking to simulate politics then you should probably look to Crusader Kings II instead. I've ragged on about these issues with the game, but really everything else is wonderful. The jobs all work out fine and building a business empire is both gratifying and cathartic. Whether you run a criminal empire of breaking into buisnesses for cash and roughing up travellers for pocket change, or a patron farmer taking their crops to market and running a local brewery, this game has countless hours of fun to offer, particularly to people who are interested in roleplaying with their friends. Especially for it's price of 99 cents at the time of this sale, I've gotten nearly 30 hours of enjoyment out of 1 USD. Buggy though it may be, I accept them considering the price of the game, and also considering they're almost never game breaking since it autosaves at the beginning of every day.

												To start, the game has a lot of bugs such as NPC's disapearing, walking in circles, karts getting permanently stuck just to name a few. While most of these are minor annoyances, they synergize with the really clunkly and awkward menus and interface. It took me a while to get anything working as a result of the difficult interface and sporadic bugs. I had to go in loops trying to figure out why I couldn't do the most simple tasks only to learn that the buttons had ceased working and my game needed to be restarted. The idea of the game seems really cool to me, but it could really use a much cleaner or clearer interface. Now IF you are able to get through the bad mechanics and like management econemy based games you will probably like this.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												I don't know where to start with this inestimable treasure to the simulation gaming world. I don't know what I like more, the frequent visual bugs, the constant presence of the black plague in maps without hospitals, or the fact that sometimes the language randomly switches to german. Designing a character is about as stimuating as Perelli's miracle elixir but unfortunately you don't get to keep that character for long because he will either die of the plague or be turned invisible by a rogue memory leak. The day to day gameplay, aside from when your guarded carts are being pillaged by old ladies and your house next to the guard's post is being robbed, is pretty standard. You build a farm and you watch your character farm. This goes on for the entire game, although occasionally you get to randomly hug people and marry them so they can bear you children who will continue to work on your farm and continue the whole ugly cycle. Despite all of this, it's the best terrible game i've ever played.

content:

												An extremely fun and time consuming game, albeit quite buggy. It's quite the sandbox, and you start out as a lowly plebian and build your way up through legitimate business or other endeavours of your choosing, which could include being a pirate, an a*shole, or a thief.The game's best mod pack can be found here: http://forum.runeforge-games.net/index.php/topic,5794.msg14581.html#msg14581 and is highly recommended if you want the best possible gameplay experience.Although I only have 10 hours on record, I put many, many hours into this game before I had it on Steam.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Well, I can't say much about this game.  From all the comments I figured it was some kind of city building meets "The Sims", but in reality I found it to be an extremely confusing and frustrating game.  From the very start I had no idea what I was doing.  My house would be robbed without me knowing how to stop it.  I spent the limited money trying to figure out how to make it back, and not succeeding.  The game is rather impossible to play without watching a lengthy tutorial, but you have to find that yourself on YouTube since I saw no sign of one in the game.  I'm glad I got this game as part of a bundle, because if I would have purchased it on it's own I would really be regretting the purchase right now.

number of helpful: 2 of 23 people (9%) found this review helpful10 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 9
												What a piece of shitake mushrooms. The learning curve is not just steep, its a sheer cliff. You have no idea what to do unless you sit through a 2 hour tutorial, where everything is unskippable video and you are unable to key in on the task you are interested in. There is no glossary and nothing is immediately obvious or intuitive. You make a person, and then...? what? buy something? It takes a while to even figure out how to move. Once you divine that you are intended to build buildings in order to create a production line, you are at a loss as to how to get people to work. I choose patron, and attempt to build a farm, only there appears to be nowhere in the city where I am allowed to build. Fine, I'll build a bakery on the one scrap of open real estate and buy the raw materials then, even at a loss at least its something. Twiddling my thumbs while it opens, I then send a cart to market to obtain flour and honey, which makes biscuits I assume from the "production" menu of my new bakery. I deliver these ingredients to the bakery, and then...what?? there is no icon anywhere to make the biscuits, all i can do is move the ingredients back and forth from the cart. None of the equipment visible in the bakery are clickable, and my new employee simply stands there like a dumb f****** cow. The production menu offers no insights, there is no button that is intuitive on how to make any items. I see "biscuits" and their ingredients listed on the left....and what? Make them, ♥♥♥♥♥! What am i supposed to do? Where is the help icons or something to identify what I need to do immediately. Even if i wanted to go back to the tutorial I would have to sit through it from the very f***** beginning! F*** this, i have better things to do with my life. Uninstall.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												This game is still an interesting and fun game. It has a lot of great ideas that could potentially be used by other games later on. I find it quiet enjoyable to play as a rogue family and make toll booths with my mercenaries so that all the carts must go through me to get the goods were they need to be. No one likes me at the end of the game though *shrug*. I enjoy owning a mine, making huge bank, and then spending that bank to actually build a bank for my Doctorate son. I enjoy running an inn, and watching all the serfs spend all their hard-earned money getting drunk after a long days work. Though this game does have some bugs, but none of which are game breaking. For instance, the AI is too pacisft, never really bothering to interrupt my family other then maybe plundering my new tiny shop, or beating up my sons second wife. I only got murdered twice in the hours I have spent. The learning curve has gotten harder, for originally in PotES, buildings were going on sale left and right, but now buildings are rarely sold, adding a bit of competition to the game. Another issue I have with the game is that titles are WAY too expensive compared to PotES and the original. I do like how becoming a nobleman to become a king is a lot harder now, but 100000 gold? I could get a baron title with that in the other games! They do add other titles to fill in the gaps with the game, but they just dont feel right to have. These things are minor things however, and can be overlooked. Most people have modded the game to fix these problems, and you can find a lot of them at Runeforge's forums.

But otherwise it is a great game, the politics is fun, the dialogue is cheesy, but in a good way, and the art syle and model design really grows on you.

												If your into roleplaying games, with rpg elements and a hint of strategy and money management.This is a game for you.You create a charecter and you choose a profession, along with a religion and stats.You customize a little bit, choose a town and family emblem.When the game starts its up to you what path you want to follow and what kind of role to play. You can get into politics and become mayor of a town, or maybe the go to guy if you need supplies and resources.You can be the dastardly rouge and commit crimes, steal, and cause grief for the town. Or be the man of honor and become the town watchmen, find and defeat the thieves and villians.Become a doctor, opening a clinic and healing the sick and broken.You could try being a clergymen and spread the good will of god, and educate the ill-informed.A simple farmer, to a noblemen of high status.It's up to you who you want to be, and find the role you want to play.You pathe your own destiny.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												As far as I'm concerned, this is the best looking historical microeconomics simulation game on the market. Admittedly a small niche, but in a world where macroeconomic grandstrategy is what gets attention, this is a nice change of pace. It can be tedious, but in the most cathartic way possible; I don't feel particularly excited when my dynasty purchases a new title - it's more of a zen sensation. The combat and wooing systems are comical, and you can pretty much amass a fortune by over saturating the market with a single, easy-to-produce item (like sugar beets). That said, I can't recommend it enough. I always seem to forget its inadequacies when I remember that it allows me to arm my monks with daggers and longswords and sic them on the town like a hyperreligious biker gang.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												This is a mixture between character building and city management.  You can focus on building your family to take over the economy, or you can run for office where you can climb your way to the top and do whatever you please without anyone questioning you because you have immunity! Or you can do both.  Plus there is the part where you show other families that you love them or just beat the dog crap out of them through politics or violence.The only down side to this game is the fact that it is buggy out the wahzoo.  By that I mean people will be sitting down on NOTHING, and a few trading carts will get stuck with other trading carts.I highly recommend buying this game instead of The Guild II or The Guild II: Pirates of the European Seas because this is not DLC, this is a GAME.  This one has all the stuff that is included in Pirates of the European Seas.I will conclude this review with this statement: If you are a little bit interested in The Guild, just buy this one.  I repeat:  DO. NOT. BUY. THE. GUILD. II.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												So glad that the newest update came out. The game is still a little buggy but no where near as bad as it was previously. If you are a fan of micromanaging and RTS games - especially for the medieval era, you should try this bad boy out. Own and operate multiple businesses (up to 999 at the highest nobility rank), use hired thugs to beat down your opponents, marry and have kids, send them to school then turn them in to assassins and either kill your enemy in the streets of the city or call him out for a duel! Or raise your children the proper way and use them to operate your various establishments, including but not limited to brothels, farms and blacksmiths.Sometimes I play for hours just to build up my businesses, make alliances with everyone and never beat the game. Just continue building and expanding. Once in awhile, i'll murder someone to keep the plebs in line though. ;-)As usual, my steam hours arent near accurate. Played this game offline, A LOT! Says i have 80 hours now, but its probably closer to 150-160.Anyways, 9/10 (would be a perfect score but due to bugs and glitches, 9 is still very good)

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												This is by far one of the most unique games I've played. In broad terms it's a game about business management and politics. It's filled with bugs and game ending crashes. It's got a slow pace and tons of micro management.  But it's fun and challenging. There's a lot of different ways to succeed, and you can play it good or bad or just mind your business. The game has lot's of issues when it comes to multiplayer. Out of sync errors are something you get used to. The auto-savings helps with that. what I love the most about it though is the silly quirks it has, weird humour and not really taking itself too seriously. Where the sims is about amassing stuff and crap; This game is about being a Citizen, political or otherwise and amassing wealth for your dynasty."You are a knave!" yes... yes... I know.9/10

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												Ok so I used to play this game back when I had the disk copy (a LOOOOOOONG time ago) and it's still fun for a plane ride or killing time when needed. The graphics are definitely outdated and it is SUPER BUGGED!!! You can even play one game, start a new one without changing any settings, and suddenly people can run for mayor without holding any office, you can buy any building regardless of type and other immersion breaking (though easily exploitable) situations.Those things aside though; BUY THIS GAME! It's just a lot of fun! Dueling an enemy who keeps running against you in office, having your goons follow people around gathering evidence against them for court, poisoning the well of the other town where your rival dynasty lives and then burning down the hospital so if, IF they survive the long trek to your hospital (which happens to be the only one left - oops), they have to pay way above the normal prices... these things are awesome! Don't like politics and running for office? Be a scholar, create the mage's guild, build a firebomb and then destroy a city! Don't feel like all that? Be a bandit - kidnap and murder people for fun! Need the life of a farmer, just making bread from the wheat you grow? .... ok. You can do that too, if you're really wanting to for some reason.It's an excellent game with a bit older graphics but tons of fun still left in it. I fully recommend it!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												If you've never played this particular franchise before then The Guild 2: Renaissance is for you.You manage a dynasty which starts with one family member and you can invest, bribe, steal or war you way to making your dynasty the monarchy.  You can increase your family insize through courtship and marriage or if you aren't into that there is always on of those ladies of the night that tends to work for Rogue operators.You can own a multitude of businesses that start from the basic type and are upgraded for a price.  Your characters profession shapes the path you can follow with which businesses you can own, however you can have 3 active dynasty members with different profession types (there are four professions to choose from)The most recent patch removes some (if not most) of the bugs in the single player game, I've not tried the multiplayer however be prepared to setup an LANoIP setup (and be ready to deal with some of the bugs that currently occur from not using a dedicated games host.)All in all, there isn't really and single game that is like The Guild and it's franchise.  It's worth checking out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												The Guild II is a fine single-player strategy game, but where it really shines is in multiplayer (LAN/Hamachi compulsory), as you conspire with a buddy to fill up all elected positions in each town or city-state, with various members of your dynasty. Once this is accomplished, the game feels as though it has run its course, but the stories generated by the hours-long journey there are fit to rival any Hollywood plot. The sheer number of options given to criminals in The Guild II is dizzying. Kidnapping, murder, bombing, arson, mugging; and these are just some of the options given to civilians, never mind the awful things you can do to rival factions, or even the Royal Family, if you are elected to a post that gives command over the city guards. That these things can be done to a rival family controlled by a human player; that you can have agents stalk other players, to witness their various crimes and report them to the authorities, or bomb their gold mine, crippling their entire production chain, makes this game an absolute joy to play. It really is something special. If you'd like to read a more in-depth review, have a look at my new site! Shameless plug, etc! http://www.firesidefrag.com/the-guild-2-jerk-politician-simulator/But seriously, look at how many hours I've clocked in. None of that was idle time. It's good.
