number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Like many other who have written reviews of this game i too have mixed feelings. It has the ye olde buisness tycoon style of other games such as the Port Royale and Patrician series (both of which i am mixed on to whether liking or hating) but with a sort of a sim style to the approach. Its a weird but interesting little mix of the buisness aspect but also controlling your own characters and how they can effect the game. Voice acting is...tolerable. I wish the developers could have just stuck with sim giberish and text boxes. The graphics are okay nothing special and yes there are a ton of bugs.    However I find that there is a lot of replay ability if you install the fanmade patch for the game as it fixes most of the games issues. There are mulitple different classes to choose, different buisnesses to operate and a political system to get involved in. However once again the AI is smart just not smart enough if you want a  major challenge. You can imprison, commit arson, kidnap, or even murder your competition and take over there buisness. Intermarrying classes works to your advantage so yo can opertate outside of your own characters limits and the generational effect is a nice touch. So i would reccomend this game because for $9.99 you get a little more than you paid for in replayability and because the concept of buisness tycoon with medieval politics and simulation is a great concept...it just wasn't done well here. I say give it a try and see what you think if you like it great if not well steam has a refund policy now.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												As far as I'm concerned, this is the best looking historical microeconomics simulation game on the market. Admittedly a small niche, but in a world where macroeconomic grandstrategy is what gets attention, this is a nice change of pace. It can be tedious, but in the most cathartic way possible; I don't feel particularly excited when my dynasty purchases a new title - it's more of a zen sensation. The combat and wooing systems are comical, and you can pretty much amass a fortune by over saturating the market with a single, easy-to-produce item (like sugar beets). That said, I can't recommend it enough. I always seem to forget its inadequacies when I remember that it allows me to arm my monks with daggers and longswords and sic them on the town like a hyperreligious biker gang.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Pretty intersting Sim-type game.  There are definitely issues with compatability and gameplay but its playable for the most part and in windowed-mode to boot.  I don't see a point in getting the original Guild II as this seems to include everything in the original and the pirates version, except for the tiny "campaign", plus a few new building/professons.  The AI is ok but seems deadset on killing you, especially members of the other dynasties when they can.  It is also quite annoying that your family members do absolutely nothing but sit in the house and die unless you control them as one of the three controlable character slots.  Seems to me they missed on one of the biggest strategies of the medeval period, that of inter-marriage of noble families to consolidate power and settle disputes.  You only have the option of courting random jobless serfs with reputations that change every time you check their profile.  Overall, especially for the minimal cost Humble Bundle had for the game, its probablly worth at least a few hours of enjoyment before becoming overly repetitive.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												yeah well.. I love these kind of games and couldn´t care less if graphics and sound and such are not state of the art. it´s the possibilities and flexibility that sets this game apart from other trade / politics / medieval industry simulations.but... and there´s always a but.. this game does lack on certain aspects. pros: -a lot of options(trader, rogue, crafstmen... it can all be done and so much more. very unique blend of RPG and trade sim..)-decent graphics for a game that oldcons: -too much micromanagementin order to have a functioning economy going, you need to almost always manage it by yourself. theres no safe way (or I just haven´t found it) to really automate the business and structures and personnel to really do what you want them towhich directly leads to the second con-politics is a pain in the buttocksin order to gain influence and climb the political ladder, you need to gain influence. but about the only thing that really worked for me (and I tried everything) was to bribe people. which is useless if everyone else does the same.I dedicated a whole new career save just to gain influence and climb the political ladder, but to no avail. when you concenrate on gaining influence, you simply run out of money. when you concentrate on making money, you will never gain enough influence. once your enemies gain enough political influence (seems they don´t have the problem micromanaging everything like I do) they can use their political powers to just jail you, accuse you, kill you, whatever. I haven´t been able to find any decent late game tutorials and descriptions and I have to agree to some other review I read: the late game purely annoys. instead of being able to concentrate on late game activities like politics, intrigue and such, you will have nothing else to do than micromanaging your economy. sure, money won´t be a problem. but it won´t help you at all. it was fun the first hours, but got old, tedious and boring pretty fast. for the price I paid it´s quiet alright. but if you expect deeper gameplay.... well. maybe you are into micromanaging. then play your heart out, this game´s for you

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												The Guild 2 with the new Renaissance upgrade is a solid game. Not perfect mind you but solid. If you are a fan of simulation games like The Sims, or are fan of business games then this game can be enjoyable for you.Pro-There are quite a few different maps available for play. So finding a change of scenery in the game is possible, but there is no way to create your own maps which is too bad. -There are a lot of different store types in the game to experiment with-There is more than just business. Family management and politics are present as well-The timeline of the game takes place in what I say is a fairly unique setting. Few games of this type take place in that area of historyCon-Although there are a lot of maps for play the replay value on this game is weak. Much of the gameplay is the same no matter which map you play on.-There is quite a clear lack of balance between the jobs in the game. Some earn fantastic amounts of money while others make close to zero even with all of there upgrades. As well a new player has no way to know this until they play more of the game.-The AI is quite weak. They are unable to build or politcally compete with the player in any meaningful way. This means that once the player has gained any bit of power they will have nothing more than limp rivals to contend.-There are many bugs in this game. I frequently found my family in the game out thousands of dollars because one of the characters could not 'find a path' to a feature. This was just one of the many that were present.All in all if you like economic games and simulators this game does have its fun. However the fun is limited and its replay becomes shortlived with the lack of functional AI. ** out of ***** for the average gamer I would say.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												To summarize, this is basically a House of Cards simulator and Frank Underwood would definitely love it (now if you liked that teaser, please keep reading haha).Despite the glitches that you can find on the game, it's extremely fun to play it. The idea is pretty much unique, as you start controlling the life of someone who has an entrepreneur spirit, meaning that you have a considerable amount of freedom to pursue a specific craft (hiring employees and everything), or maybe engaging in politics. Besides that, the person that you create can also get married with other people and have children, which is something that increases the number of members on the family (it's a shame that you can only control 3 of them at the same time). In order to survive and to win the game, you literally need to find a way to eradicate all the means of competition (rival families). The fun part is that you can use your creativity to find ways to do that. For example, depending of your political position in the government, you can literally be untouchable, in other words, you may hire assassins to remove certain people out of the way and also destroy your rivals' buildings without having to worry about further consequences. You can be promoted to further rankings in politics simply by flattering with influential people and that goes for the 3 people that you control at the same time. Just a friendly advice: Don't forget to apply the latest patch! Have fun *evil laugh*.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Quick run over the game and its mechanics..You start selecting your character, skills and essentially decide how you want to be the surviving dynasty. There isnt really any backstory as such. Imagine this game to be an arena styled game.. However, to win you use politics, business, sabotage, alchemy and more to defeat your opposition.You can be the scum of the earth, killing the opposition by using henchman to burn down their businesses or house.You become a king and sentence your opposition to prison and in some instances death.Or you can build a business, wait for disease to strike and use money to keep your self and family healthy and clean.In all honesty, anything goes.This game is fantastic, random, and the AI are actually quite smart.for i.e you want to get into politics, however, the entire monarch is based around a singular family and as such only vote for their own family members therefore making it very difficult to progress.The only way you can get to the top is through brides, charisma and assasinations..This being said, there are alot of bugs with the game.Inactivity bugs, save bugs, global market bugs, building placement bugs and more..but..It isnt easy to pick up either, there really isn't much of tutorial, took me about 5 hours to pick it up tbh.the game is WAAYYY to fun and unpredictable to stop playing.9/10 ♥♥♥♥ing great game

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												I've had a lot of fun with this title, but it does start to fall apart after long-running games. I experienced massive slow-downs after more than seven or eight generations and various save and load errors. Regardless, the game is great and a great example of the real-time strategy format. I've simply modified my game type selections so I don't end up playing that long during a single session. Considering that it starts to feel like a bit of a grind around that point anyway, I don't mind the sacrifice.There are a few aspects of this game that make it stand out in its genre. The continuation of your lineage's goals over several generations, for instance, is a unique approach and adds an entire realm of activities outside of your standard economy-driven real-time strategies. Imagine adding the Sims to your favorite RTS. If that doesn't sound like fun to you, no worries, you can play out your life as a lonely hermit who doesn't get involved with the town's social affairs. There are enough game type choices that make this just as entertaining an option.If you like real-time strategies, and the medeival format entices you, I'd highly recommend giving this game a try; that is, if you can get past the dated graphics. I certainly can. If the latest graphics are a hard requirement for you, skip this one; you won't enjoy it.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												If you've never played this particular franchise before then The Guild 2: Renaissance is for you.You manage a dynasty which starts with one family member and you can invest, bribe, steal or war you way to making your dynasty the monarchy.  You can increase your family insize through courtship and marriage or if you aren't into that there is always on of those ladies of the night that tends to work for Rogue operators.You can own a multitude of businesses that start from the basic type and are upgraded for a price.  Your characters profession shapes the path you can follow with which businesses you can own, however you can have 3 active dynasty members with different profession types (there are four professions to choose from)The most recent patch removes some (if not most) of the bugs in the single player game, I've not tried the multiplayer however be prepared to setup an LANoIP setup (and be ready to deal with some of the bugs that currently occur from not using a dedicated games host.)All in all, there isn't really and single game that is like The Guild and it's franchise.  It's worth checking out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												The concept of this game is good but the execution is rather poor.  I enjoy the idea of this game and I am entertained enough to stick around awhile and try to play it despite its flaws, but there's no question that it deserves the low metacritic score it has.  The game has some major shortcomings that should have been resolved at release and I cannot recommend it due to those shortcomings.  I'll list a few of them:If you slow down the gameplay it also slows down your user interface for instance.  There's no excuse for that.  Telling your wagons where to go should be responsive whether you are paused or playing in fast forward, but because of the way the wagon command ui is tied to the world movement ticks entering commands for them at low speeds is slow and annoying.The pause feature is fairly buggy.  It stops time but some of the people are still moving around in slow motion the whole time you are "paused".   This is probably because the wagons and such would be completely unresponsive if they were actually completely paused due to their response to commands being tied to their movement.Sometimes my character becomes unresponsive and it wont respond to any commands anymore.  I end up having to save and reload the game just to get it to work again.  I'm sure this is also related to the buggy pause feature.Pathfinding is sometimes buggy and people will get stuck at one spot on the map and just turn in a circle repeatedly.  This is fairly rare but has happened to both my characters and the AI characters in my game.  One time I saw 20 AI stuck at one spot with my wagon and I had to save and reload the game to get everybody moving again.I still can't figure out if you are actually supposed to eat in the game.  The only time I fed two of my characters a biscuit both of them contracted tooth rot which I couldn't even treat because there was no hospital in my game.  When I run a shop I place items for sale in it that other people can buy, but when I go into the npcs shops they never seem to have anything for sale so I have to buy everything at the market.  This works, but it breaks the immersion of the game.  The tutorial has no coverage at of food or equipment or artifacts at all.  Note that there's only a tutorial currently if you download the 4.20 beta.  The base version of the game has no tutorial at all.The user interface for analyzing the profitability of your business ventures is poor.  You can't tell how much each individual business is earning or losing.  You just get some totals that encompass all your business and house expense into an end of month total.  You have no easy way to tell how much you are earning or losing on individual products in a business.I tried to participate in politics.  The political board listed the requirement as Citizen for almost all of the positions and it did not specify a level requirement, but when I bought my way up to Citizen and tried to apply for one it told me I wasn't high enough.  Either there's a hidden level requirement too or the requirement page for politics doesn't list the actual rank requirements. Anyway, you've been warned.  If you have too much time on your hands like me and you want to play a mediocre game that only costs a few bucks on sale, then go for it, but you should not pay more than a few dollars for this game.  You can get some entertainment out of it if you are willing to deal with its faults.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2012
												A lot of work has been done to get rid of the (many) rough edges on this title.  The AI is much better.  Pathfinding bugs are mostly gone.  And the economic system functions almost perfectly, which is to say it's a challenge.When you do get a supply chain settled, things can work quite smoothly.  I'd advise you to use the AI management after you get one or two businesses.  It costs a bit of money in game, but the micro saved is well worth it for how much you can focus on other things.There's about 20 different approaches you can take to become successful in the cities of each map.  But the highlight for me is developing your family and seeing them grow and interact with others, although I've never really gotten anywhere politically.PS. I have one copy of this game in my inventory.  If you're interested in receiving it, leave some comment to this review telling me what you think of it, as well as why you're not able to buy it yourself.  OR tell me about a friend of yours who can't really afford this, but you'd like to play it with them.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												The Guild 2 Renaissance is, well, quite the different game and it's hard to pin down. Imagine if you will a cocktail, three parts The Sims, two parts Crusader Kings and a dash of any German made simulator game. Shake well and you've got yourself The Guild 2.Now I think it's best to point out that I have not played most of the game modes available. I have played the dynasty mode which is kind of just the games free roam mode where there’s no quests or objectives apart from keeping your family/dynasty alive much like Crusader Kings.So the first thing you do is pick a map, this entails what villages, towns and cities you'll have in your world and the environment. I pick the "Sheriff of Nottingham" map since it was smaller, had a village and a town to work on and well...you know...Robin hood n'♥♥♥♥♥♥Then I picked my family shield, which also dictates the colour of your dynasties’ clothing, so naturally I went for bright orange to show my power or some such and then went on to make the founder of my dynasty, one Benn Grey. Good old Benn, was a rogue one of the four classes in the game and the more...violent and backhanded of the classes making his money and way in the world collecting a toll from passing traders dotting the road since personally I found earning money the more legal way was pretty dam tough and will take a lot of learning on the players part. As for most jobs you'll have to buy/make ingredients then make whatever your business makes, from bread to bracelets made out of bones stolen from a graveyard and sell these items in different markets and counting houses or otherwise risk lowering the buying price of your goods till you can barely make any profit anymore. Whereas being a rogue all I had to do was kidnap, murder or force people to pay a toll. Hey it's a dirty job....but I'd rather do it.So with that in mind, I set forth to make old Benn Grey the most feared gangster of the 1400's. I built my own personal merc castle and started forcing people to pay a toll just for walking through the market place, which everyone hated me for so when looking for a wife to pop out a baby and keep my family line strong, nobody wanted to marry me. So I did the smart thing and brought my own wife, good old Linette who totally didn't mind me buying her off her family. She was a Craftswoman so with my extra money I bought her a little forge to make weapons for my mercs so I would be unstoppable! She also did pop out a brat so all was looking up for Benn.So the next stop would of course be for Benn to get political power. Which in my humble view is the best part of the game. Bribing people, flirting and killing your way to the top feels so dam good and it's tough but not too tough so you feel like you have to plan and slither your way to be mayor. With Benn being a rogue I wanted him to be the village mayor because it granted him the ability to embezzle public funds and not be arrested for any crime he committed, and so sure I was that I would get the office I murdered the captain of the guard in the market in front of everyone and shot the mayor in a duel after kissing her in a pub and then calling her a ♥♥♥♥♥ after she slapped me. After this I thought I was unstoppable, until I lost my campaign to be mayor when the victor, a woman from a rival dynasty won by having her name pulled out of a hat since everyone who could vote had been killed by me. Then poor Benn was put on trial for killing the mayor and captain of the guard in public and since he didn't have the immunity he craved, was sentenced to death. After screaming "OH YOU'RE NEXT!" at the judge he was taken out side and had his head lopped off right where he killed the captain. A somewhat fitting end when you think about it.Finally poor Linette tried to avenge her husband by getting the Mayor’s office and killing the judge but failed over and over losing all her money in bribes selling the castle and her forge and then getting a cold and dying since she never had the coin for medicine.Overall if you enjoy roleplaying and have a stronger imagination this game is great. Oh the stories you can spin about your dynasty. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll kill your way to the top before dying from a sprained ankle and leave a two year old boy an orphan. Although you'll just as easily get muddled in the economics of the game and crash the market for grain.Personally speaking the role-play value is a 7/10, but is more like a 8/10 if you put the effort to understand the economics.I hope to see you all soon buying wives and killing mayors in this gem of a game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												This game has a core game play that is really fun and unique. Build a dynasty through trade, shadowy power and political intrigue.At first with only one or two business, things go well. You start earning money and feel a sense of accomplishment as your fledging trade empire grows. You notice a few problems and bugs such as a pause system that work by slowing down the game to a crawl and also, slow down your user interations to a crawl, pathing issues where npcs get stuck, your char keep running and stopping behind an npc, trying to interact with him/her never succeeding, but still tolerable.Then you got robbed. Which is fine, wealth is nothing without the force to defend it. You hire guards to patrol your buildings and defend you. And you got rob again. You stare in disbelieve as your char and guards do nothing as you order them to attack (possible pathing bug?), only after the thief is running away then your guards start chasing futilely. Ok, lesson learned. You build watch towers right in front of your structures, build a mercenary fortress and plant mercenaries right in front of your shop in toll collecting mode, security and money making, both at sametime, seems to work.As time goes on, your trade empire grows and you start getting annoyed with all the micomanagement required to make sure supply flows smoothly or else the whole chain will grind to a halt. You tweak your trade routes such that they move just the "right" amount of goods without flooding the recipent (a shop with no space storage cannot produce stuff) and constantly move crafted good from storage to sale slot because there is no way to automate that. When you think that maybe, just maybe you can get this under control, you accidentally end the day with a negative balance after your employees are paid and your whole house of cards came crashing down. All trade routes cancels when your balance become negative, carts halt right in front of the stall they are suppose to sell to.Ok fine, maybe you know, this game isn't suppose to be micromanaged? You turn over the shops to the AI and build structures from the rouge tree (which doesn't need resources and require min micromanagement). Things start to get managable again. You start getting a good feeling, maybe soon you will be able to finish upgrading all your buildings and start running for office.Then the game crash. Well, tough luck, good thing you as a veteran gamer have the good habit of saving regularly. You load the last save... and the game crash immediately again. You load the save before the last, and the game crash again.- End of review

Posted: April 4, 2015
												G2 is a decent game, but the micro-management of the shops is a royal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥  If you set up buildings to support a supply chain, you have to keep transferring the goods manually to make that happen.  AI manager doesn't understand supply chains and doesn't try to maximize profit (Read:  At all).  While this isn't too much of a bother when you only have a couple shops, once you get a couple supply chains up and running, it's just way too much micro-management to have time to do anything else in the game.  If I could specify I wanted to keep 40 oak, 40 pine, 40 gems, 40 pins, and 40 gold in my Joinery, using my own raw materials buildings as a preferred source; and to sell crafted products to the market when there were 20 in stock...  The game would be so damn much more enjoyable.As it is, it's just micro-management hell and tedium.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												The concept of this game is good but the execution is rather poor.  I enjoy the idea of this game and I am entertained enough to stick around awhile and try to play it despite its flaws, but there's no question that it deserves the low metacritic score it has.  The game has some major shortcomings that should have been resolved at release and I cannot recommend it due to those shortcomings.  I'll list a few of them:If you slow down the gameplay it also slows down your user interface for instance.  There's no excuse for that.  Telling your wagons where to go should be responsive whether you are paused or playing in fast forward, but because of the way the wagon command ui is tied to the world movement ticks entering commands for them at low speeds is slow and annoying.The pause feature is fairly buggy.  It stops time but some of the people are still moving around in slow motion the whole time you are "paused".   This is probably because the wagons and such would be completely unresponsive if they were actually completely paused due to their response to commands being tied to their movement.Sometimes my character becomes unresponsive and it wont respond to any commands anymore.  I end up having to save and reload the game just to get it to work again.  I'm sure this is also related to the buggy pause feature.Pathfinding is sometimes buggy and people will get stuck at one spot on the map and just turn in a circle repeatedly.  This is fairly rare but has happened to both my characters and the AI characters in my game.  One time I saw 20 AI stuck at one spot with my wagon and I had to save and reload the game to get everybody moving again.I still can't figure out if you are actually supposed to eat in the game.  The only time I fed two of my characters a biscuit both of them contracted tooth rot which I couldn't even treat because there was no hospital in my game.  When I run a shop I place items for sale in it that other people can buy, but when I go into the npcs shops they never seem to have anything for sale so I have to buy everything at the market.  This works, but it breaks the immersion of the game.  The tutorial has no coverage at of food or equipment or artifacts at all.  Note that there's only a tutorial currently if you download the 4.20 beta.  The base version of the game has no tutorial at all.The user interface for analyzing the profitability of your business ventures is poor.  You can't tell how much each individual business is earning or losing.  You just get some totals that encompass all your business and house expense into an end of month total.  You have no easy way to tell how much you are earning or losing on individual products in a business.I tried to participate in politics.  The political board listed the requirement as Citizen for almost all of the positions and it did not specify a level requirement, but when I bought my way up to Citizen and tried to apply for one it told me I wasn't high enough.  Either there's a hidden level requirement too or the requirement page for politics doesn't list the actual rank requirements. Anyway, you've been warned.  If you have too much time on your hands like me and you want to play a mediocre game that only costs a few bucks on sale, then go for it, but you should not pay more than a few dollars for this game.  You can get some entertainment out of it if you are willing to deal with its faults.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												On my CD copy I have put in 100's of hours in to this game. It's my favorite game of all time because of the amount of freedom the game allows the player to have. I love playing as a rouge building a criminal empire and taking control of the city. The game takes 3 very different generes and puts them together to make a fantastic sandbox style game. You take control of a character who is the start of a long family line. You get married have kids to continue your families legacy and start a (Hopefully) lucrative Business to make money and compete in the local econmic market. Your family can get involved in city polictics and compete for higher seats of office. There are so many ways to play this game. I only wish that multiplayer was a little more stable because if it was this would be an awesome multiplayer experience. To end this review all I can say is I can't wait for the Guild 3 and I hope you give this game a try!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												- Pick a profession out of many possibilities. Sounds interesting!- Construct your business building which allows you to produce several specific goods- Produce the goods from resources that you either collect, buy or produce yourself- Sell goods either at the business or at one of the markets on the map- Update the building and hire more workers as money permits- Repeat with as many businesses as you like- Grow boredResources that you can collect never run out. You can send a bunch of workers to pick that same small spot of lavender flowers for decades.Resources that you grow never fluctuate. I never had a bad harvest.Production rates are steady, too. I've never had a problem with my workers or any noticable difference in their output.Seasons don't provide variation either. While the game has nice visuals for the seasons and even tells you that transports move slower in winter, you can harvest just as many flowers, fruits or grain in the deepest snow.There are only 3 levels of each building and very similar minor updates. I maxed out 6 businesses within a generation of my dynasty and now they are just sitting there.Goods are often weirdly specific or illogical. A lvl 2 inn can only offer a salmon and mushroom dish for food, so you better get salmon and mushrooms, no alternative. A lvl 1 bank produces copper coins from iron (by magic?).Goods never spoil. Harvest a ton of fruit and sell them 20 years later, who cares?Even places that should be about providing services are not. As a healer you earn most by selling soap you make out of lavender.As soon as you own a chain of supply, there's nothing left to do. Buy a farm, a mill and bakery, and spend the rest of your life moving icons of grain and wheat around, yay!tl;dr: Maybe you could have a little fun with a criminal or political career, but the economy and building mechanics lack any dynamic or complexity that might make them interesting or challenging.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												The main reason I'll recommend this game is because you get a ton of value for the price if you get it on discount. It's more or less a medieval version of sims♥♥♥♥♥business tycoon♥♥♥♥♥political simulator.+Many types of businesses you can choose to run in the game, each filling a certain market demand, and your town grows as you hire more employees.+Interesting political aspect to the game, including elections, where you climb your way up the political ladder for more privileges like immunity from the law.+Many options to dealing with your enemies, including dueling, defamation, taking them to court, kidnapping, or just plain murder.And now with the cons:-AI is terrible at managing certain high level businesses. It’s frankly quite broken and doesn’t do what it’s supposed to do.-Market demand is non existent for certain products. They will remain on the market  pretty much forever and depress the price. The AI doesn’t know how to utilize some of the higher level items and will never buy or make use of them against you.-Indicator during politics or court sessions not always reliable at predicting the result.-AI is more or less passive and relatively peaceful, making it pretty much impossible to be killed by one and thus lose the game. Even if you fast forward the game 40 years, the AI even at their meanest doesn’t go around killing people for the most part and while fighting amongst themselves not one of them will eliminate another. If any one of them is going to die it will be because of the player.My overall impression is that the game had a pretty good and unique concept, but it was executed somewhat poorly. After all the patching it is pretty playable, but still somewhat buggy. Again, the main reason I’ll recommend it is because if you get it on discount, the value you get blows many other games you can get at a similar price point out of the water. Another thing to add is that the Guild 3 is supposedly coming out this year, so you can treat this game a bit like a preview as to what you may expect from the upcoming sequel.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												After 10 hours of play time I can confidently recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of sim, rpg, time or economy  management games.Having said that there are a few caveats.1. You must patch the game to the latest 4.211 (there are many posts about how to do this as it's not straight forward)2. Even after patching it you will see some bugs (e.g. pathing problems, UI glitches). You'll have to make peace with the fact they will never be fixed.3. Watch a tutorial video or be prepared for frustration the first couple of hours. The in game tutorial is ♥♥♥♥e.I myself did not watch or read up on how to play and it made the first couple of hours very annoying but during that time there was still enough intersting game play that it made me want to keep going. I'm glad I did because the very entertaining scenarios that arise during the game are endlessly entertaining to me. It also helps if you like to use your imagination. If you have ever played the sims maybe you have done like I have and made up back stories for sims and especially for explaining the decisions they make. I'm having  a blast doing the same in the Guild 2 Renaissance.If you're on the fence put this one on your wish list and wait for it to go on sale. it's definitely worth a buy then.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												This is a great game. Excellent economic and political sim that makes you really feel involved in your character and their family. A few bugs here and there but any game has them. The game runs a bit clanky at times, but if you have the patience to wait through the bugs and problems, and you SAVE OFTEN, it's endless hours of fun. As for mods, I havent even touched Fajeths mod pack yet, and I am still enjoying the game.I only have one warning; Make sure you buy ONLY this game, and not The Guild Gold Edition or any of the other The Guild II versions. They are all standalones, not expansions, and Renaissance is the most updated with the final update coming in 2015. Dont waste your money on the bundle either, because this is most likely the only game you will play in the bundle. However, praise to the devs for working on a game so long after it's release.All in all, give it a shot. The game really isnt that expensive and as far as simulators go, it is one of the best I have played in years.

												A lot of work has been done to get rid of the (many) rough edges on this title.  The AI is much better.  Pathfinding bugs are mostly gone.  And the economic system functions almost perfectly, which is to say it's a challenge.When you do get a supply chain settled, things can work quite smoothly.  I'd advise you to use the AI management after you get one or two businesses.  It costs a bit of money in game, but the micro saved is well worth it for how much you can focus on other things.There's about 20 different approaches you can take to become successful in the cities of each map.  But the highlight for me is developing your family and seeing them grow and interact with others, although I've never really gotten anywhere politically.PS. I have one copy of this game in my inventory. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												After few years of building my small patron empire, I had THE oppurtunity to take over my rival's only business, fully upgrade windmill. By throwing fire bombs at it until it, I guess, burned into submission. Lost a lot of good hired men, but I had crippled the enemy dynasty, which was nearly dead by now because of the plague that ravaged the city. But, as people tend to do, she told the city council and I was to be punished for my crimes. So I hid my kid away and while doing that my male character caught the Black Death. And by the time the hearing started he was on his death bed.So my female character (whom I forgot to level up) went in and faced the charges. I was charged with: vandalism, robbery, theft, attacking a guard and tripple murder (her thugs did nit agree with me taking over her property, so I convicnced them with my sharp tong- I mean blade. And there was no way she would not win that trial. But seconds before the court asked me to tell my version of the story, I remembered -- I could raise my Charisma and Rhetoric. With Ch and R at 10/10 (IGN approves), I blew the judge away with my grabbing speech. Also, I found out that one of the guards was infected with plague and that both me and the executioner were freshly sick.After my epic speech the court single-handedly said NOT GUILTY, and I was to choose proper punishment for my rival. I adviced 40 years in prison, which for a single childless woman meant the end of her dynasty. And jst for the fun of it I asked for 5k of gold. Got her in jail and got the gold, with my social status being better than ever before.As the guards and the executioner took her out of the court room, my female character suddenly collapsed, died right there, because plague + age + stress = bad blood. And just like that, after my glorious triumph and mere seconds before my child reached the age he was considered adult (after each day the time fast forwards one or four years into the future), I lost it all -- because kids can't run The Guild, right?Recommended: But of course! I still have to make it as the National Executioner, and so should you!(About my playtime: I got this game from my local store and got the Steam version to save myself the trouble of looking for the DVD I somehow managed to lose; estimated playtime: 100+ hours)

												G2 is a decent game, but the micro-management of the shops is a royal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥  If you set up buildings to support a supply chain, you have to keep transferring the goods manually to make that happen. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												The Guild 2 with the new Renaissance upgrade is a solid game. Not perfect mind you but solid. If you are a fan of simulation games like The Sims, or are fan of business games then this game can be enjoyable for you.Pro-There are quite a few different maps available for play. So finding a change of scenery in the game is possible, but there is no way to create your own maps which is too bad. -There are a lot of different store types in the game to experiment with-There is more than just business. Family management and politics are present as well-The timeline of the game takes place in what I say is a fairly unique setting. Few games of this type take place in that area of historyCon-Although there are a lot of maps for play the replay value on this game is weak. Much of the gameplay is the same no matter which map you play on.-There is quite a clear lack of balance between the jobs in the game. Some earn fantastic amounts of money while others make close to zero even with all of there upgrades. As well a new player has no way to know this until they play more of the game.-The AI is quite weak. They are unable to build or politcally compete with the player in any meaningful way. This means that once the player has gained any bit of power they will have nothing more than limp rivals to contend.-There are many bugs in this game. I frequently found my family in the game out thousands of dollars because one of the characters could not 'find a path' to a feature. This was just one of the many that were present.All in all if you like economic games and simulators this game does have its fun. However the fun is limited and its replay becomes shortlived with the lack of functional AI. ** out of ***** for the average gamer I would say.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 6
												I bought the Guild II Renaissance approx. 7 years after it was released. Usually you expect games like that to not be up to the time and to feel weird an rusty. Most of the time (at least for me) they are not a lot of fun. The Guild II, especially Renaissance however is an amazingly fun game that aged better than any Elder Scrolls or Battlefield. This game still has hundreds of hours of fun in store despite its age. There have admittedly been some problems in the past especially with the online aspect of the game. I personally think playing this with your friends is one of the most fun an durable online game experiences on  the market. If you like RPG elements and/or simple economic principals in games you will have a blast with the Guild II. I had a bug that caused my rogue character to kill cart drivers to not be able to take their stuff, wich made it essentially useless for me to do it. However the spirit of the game makes it up and the bug turned into part of the lore of this character that grew and grew until I even made a small audiobook for my friends about htis character. Get this game and be surprised. It has more to offer than you might think. My recommendation: Wait for this to be on sale and BUY it! You don´t need the original, just buy Renaissance, as it is more refinded and has more to offer. Steam routinely puts this down to 2,50€ and that is just a great deal. DEAR THQ NORDIC AND RUNE FORGE,I am very much looking forward to playing the third part of your wonderful game series, as this is one of my all time favorites! So if you read this, wich is highly unlikely, but anyway, THANK YOU! Thank you for so many hours of fun and joy with your games!I would also take a free version of The Guild III if you insist!Much love from Germany,Your Birdy

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												---New Review---Many people have said, through various locations on the internet, that this is a game that should be forgotten, and the series died at the first game but I can't help but disagree!Theres something about this game I just love! I think its the difficulty curve. If you play on Easy you'll struggle to actually find a foothold in your chosen field the first few (tens of) times you play, or at least; you will if you're like me, but once you find the profession that  suits your play style and you find the strategy that works you'll find it becomes pretty simple to carve out the lineage that you know you deserve.For the most part thats what I love about The Guild 2: Renaissance; the fact that its still amazingly fun even when you know what you're doing and  (In my opinion) even fun without challenge.When you get bored of that you'll be tempted to turn up the diffculty; call me an unskilled gamer if you like but I dont do that anymore... I simply find the  difficulty too hard and its not what I play the game for! Okay, so this review has been a little rambly but the point I'm trying to make is that this game is truly great, its great with massive amounts of challenge (Although thats not how I like to play it) and its great with basically no challenge. Its a very adaptable game, you can play it seriously and in "I AM BEST GAMER IN WORLD! HEAR ME ROAR!!" mode or you can play it in "My names Doris, I'm a mother of 4 and like a nice simple game to pass the time" mode.Buy it you fool!---Original Review---Despite what you may read/hear else where on the internet; this game genuinly is brilliant.Its a game that truly stands apart from others in its rather specific group. Its about being a nobody with dreams of being MORE than somebody.You create a character, build a business, buy some stuff, then die.Then you try again; Create, Build, Buy, Sell, Get murdered.And again: Create, Build, Buy, Plague.And again: Create, Build, Dysentary.Again: Create, Build, Buy, Sell, Marry, Children, Die, Children take over, Build more, Buy More, Get arrested, Die in prison.Give up.Wait six months and repeat.If that sounds like something you'd enjoy then get this game! (This one is also the best of the series so dont bother buying the others.)

Posted: December 1, 2014
												On my CD copy I have put in 100's of hours in to this game. It's my favorite game of all time because of the amount of freedom the game allows the player to have. I love playing as a rouge building a criminal empire and taking control of the city. The game takes 3 very different generes and puts them together to make a fantastic sandbox style game. You take control of a character who is the start of a long family line. You get married have kids to continue your families legacy and start a (Hopefully) lucrative Business to make money and compete in the local econmic market. Your family can get involved in city polictics and compete for higher seats of office. There are so many ways to play this game. I only wish that multiplayer was a little more stable because if it was this would be an awesome multiplayer experience. To end this review all I can say is I can't wait for the Guild 3 and I hope you give this game a try!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 1
												I'm going to preface this review by saying that if lack of bugs is an important quality in a game for you, then you will probably hate this game.I have played every iteration of The Guild 2(as well as the first game). Since it was first released, I have played much of this game in various forms long before purchasing it on Steam. Renaissance is, by far, the best form of The Guild 2 that there is. If you had played the earlier forms of the game, you would understand why I love Renaissance so much. Is this game bug free? Absolutely not. It has had a rocky development and maintenance history. It has been more or less abandoned on more than one occassion. Yet, it's still here, and people are actively developing mods for this game. That's because the gameplay concepts presented are an absolute home run. While it's basically meant to be business sim and rpg, it succeeds by offering diverse ways of playing the game. Sure, you can buy materials, make them into a finished product, and sell your finished goods at a profit. Absolutely. You can also use those finished goods to arm mercenaries who will extort money from passersby. Or you can use other finished goods to improve your chances of gaining political office. You could also rob a plump, plentiful shop for your income. And wouldn't it be nice if you could use your politlcal influence to gain control of the city guard and prevent guards from patrolling near that shop you want to rob? Yes, you can do that, and that is what makes this game great. It's worth noting that that is just the possibilities offered by one class, the Rogue.Honestly, what makes this game great, for me, boils down to the fact that you have a lot of different things that you can do. In most business sims, materials and goods are just icon swaps for each other with different numbers representing their utility. In The Guild 2: Renaissance, the utility of goods extends beyond simple, numerical values. Have a rival Dynasty in the same business as you in your city, constantly beating you to the punch by selling in your city's market and lowering the economic value of your goods? Sure, you COOOOULD just sell your goods at a different city's market. IF YOU'RE A COMMUNIST. Instead, show them whatfor by setting off a stink bomb in their firm. They can't very well sell goods they haven't made, can they?Now, here is where reality bites. This game is buggy. Buggy to the point where I simply won't run the game without installing a modpack. Lucky for you, there are many great mods available. To make things even better, you have two great options for mod packs. Fajeth's Mega Modpack and McCoy's Legacy Modpack. Both of these are great. While they both include a lot of similar mods Mega Modpack is geared towards adding more item options, and Legacy Modpack is geared more towards improving the multiplayer experience. On the latter note, if you're looking for a good multiplayer experience, this game is a mixed bag. On the one hand, multiplayer is awesome. On the other hand, multiplayer was poorly implemented in this game. Legacy Modpack has made a lot of improvements, but even with that and following all advice offered by the community on avoiding them, you still may end up with OOS errors. And the advice goes pretty far. Last I checked they even mentioned playing with the same exact video settings (turning most graphics features off). If you can get a good group going, the multiplayer can be extremely fun and rewarding. Mario Party has nothing on this game in terms of ruining friendships.I recommend this game if you're a patient person who is okay with having to deal with bugs. You have a lot of fun ways to play the game, and its particular blend of gameplay concepts is unique. The game offers a lot in terms of actual roleplaying, and it charmingly begs you to immerse yourself in its quirky world.EDIT: I can't wait for The Guild 3!

Hopefully in the new version, they will add options to family size and or provide an easier interface to track all of the activities occuring in game.  There were a couple of times where I would look for a worker or Mercenary and they were dead or just simply vanished...  But overall, I haven't had this much fun in a game since Medieval Total War II; Total War being more about the Combat and The Guild being more about the operations of a Pre-Nobility family.
